CORD-19
  • CORD-19 Study Carrels

The Distant Reader Meets COVID-19

This is the home page of a HPC Consortium sponsored project entitled, "Analyzing and enhancing CORD-19 and additional Coronavirus-related data sets". Since the project is using a thing called the Distant Reader as its core technology, this project is colloquially referred to as "The Distant Reader Meets COVID-19".

Goal

Our goal is three-fold. First, we are going to harvest and enhance the CORD data set. We will then re-distribute the enhancement along with appropriate documentation. Second, we will create sets of Distant Reader "study carrels" all on the topic of COVID-19. One of those study carrels will include the whole of CORD. Third, we will create sets of study carrels intended to address questions found on Kaggle.

Sponsors

This site is a result of sponsorship from the HPC Consortium. More specifically, we are working with folks from XSEDE (Jetstream), LANL, and Microsoft.

Contact us

As of right now, the best way to answer the question, "Who are you gonna call?", is to email Eric Morgan <emorgan@nd.edu>. In all sincerity, feel free to send him a note.

Outputs

To date we have created a set of fledgling Distant Reader "study carrels". Ultimately students, researchers, and scholars can use these study carrels to "read" large corpora of literature on the topic of COVID-19.

[Insert here links to "cord-enhanced", our extended features version of cord]

There are a number of Kaggle question challanges, and we have begun to address them. Some of the challenges include:

  • collaboration
  • diagnostics & surveillance
  • ethics & social science
  • interventions
  • medical care
  • origin, evolution, and genetics
  • risk factors
  • transmission, incubation, and stability
  • vaccines & theraputics

Links

There are a number of "channels" you can use to get involved or learn more:

  • We use Slack as our primary mode of internal communication, and anybody & everybody is allowed join - http://bit.ly/distantreader-on-slack
  • Our code is on GitHub, and we also use GitHub as a sort of ticketing system so you can see what we are doing - https://github.com/ericleasemorgan/reader
  • There is a Twitter feed, but it is mostly about our underlying technology, a thing we call the Distant Reader - https://twitter.com/readerdistant
  • Similarly, there are a number of blog postings which describe many aspects of the Distant Reader - http://sites.nd.edu/emorgan/category/distant-reader/
